Thank you for your patience and flexibility at this time.

Gracias por su paciencia y flexibilidad en este momento.

Todd Lile, Superintendent

Madera Unified would like to recognize the 53 seniors who have earned the California Seal of Biliteracy for the 2019-20 school year.
Madera High School educated 10 students to full bilingualism in Spanish and English and Madera South High School inspired 39 Spanish language honorees and 4 trilingual honorees in French, Spanish and English.
Each honoree will receive a gold embossed insignia from the state of CA on their diploma and certificate of achievement. The student's transcript will indicate that they have earned the SSB and this achievement will serve them well for a lifetime.
We deeply appreciate parents, teachers, and MUSD staff who have supported biliteracy and bilingualism and we believe these outstanding students will help us build a more inclusive and optimistic future. The district is very proud of their work all the way through their school years and despite our recent crisis, their future success should be full of confidence! The Seniors were celebrated with music, balloons, and cheers while picking up their cap & gowns as well as their first alumni gear which included a (canvas) "Senior Swag" bag, stickers, and a yard sign. It was a great day filled with emotions as the graduates were able to get a little slice of normalcy during these unprecedented times. Plans are still being worked and the district will be communicating what they are very soon. Thank you to ABC30 Action News KSEE24 News Univision FOX26 for airing our district story. #MaderaUnified #SchoolDistrict #WeBelieveMUSD #StrongerTogether

The Madera Leo Club, which is made up of 50 members from both Madera High School and Madera South High School, visited several elementary schools this week to donate new shoes and socks to students. The Census is Coming April 1, 2020

How many questions are on the Census?
Contrary to popular belief, the Census has only nine questions. Census questions include name, age, country of origin/race, gender, and if the person filling out the Census survey owns or rents the home at that address. Additionally, they will NOT ask for your citizenship.

By law, the U.S.Census Bureau must keep all personal information private. They are not allowed to share your information with anyone, including other government agencies.

Help ensure Madera County families are in the know and Get Counted! Feel free to share our message to support a complete Census 2020 count for all!

﻿To learn more about the upcoming census, visit 2020census.gov.

Madera Unified received a donation of medical supplies worth over $500 from Pistoresi Ambulance to help school sites in case of a medical emergency. Madera Unified purchased 11 rapid response bags that were stocked with the donated medical supplies which include a variety of trauma bandages, medical tape, shears, and other medical items. Thank you Pistoresi Ambulance for your support of our students safety.

The bags will be located in mobile security units and at major school sites throughout the school district. According to Lawrence Fernandez, Madera Unified Safety and Security Manager, the accessibility to these medical bags is crucial since they give school staff and Madera Police Department School Resource Officers the option of immediate treatment at the scene of an emergency, pending advance medical personnel and equipment to arrive. #MaderaUnified #SchoolDistrict #CommunitySupport #WeBelieve

Workshops ranged from understanding challenging student behaviors, Central Valley gangs, eating healthy and reducing stress to Graphic Design 101. On December 12, 2019, Madera Unified along with the Madera County Probation Dept. hosted an Alternate Education Flag Football Tournament at Memorial Stadium where students from Mountain Vista High School, Ripperdan, and Pioneer Technical participated. Schools from outside the district were also invited and included Village Oaks(Stockton), Yosemite High and Sequoia(Merced), Los Banos, Madera Juvenile Academy, and CDS/Aftercare Program. Madera Unified’s Mountain Vista High School won the tournament!
According to Marlene Aguilar, who is a Probation Program Specialist and event coordinator, many of the students are considered at risk or are attending continuation schools and look forward to events such as these.
“These students have not been exposed to any type of sport and these tournaments offer them an opportunity to try a sport and be a part of a team while developing their social skills and visiting other schools. This also encourages them to get back into mainstream schooling,” said Aguilar.
#MaderaUnified #SchoolDistrict #MUSD #WeBelieve #FlagFootball

It is with tremendous sadness that we address the loss of one of our students, Josephine Jimenez. As we mourn the loss of our student, we offer sympathy, prayers, and comfort to the family, friends, classmates, teachers and everyone who loved her and shared in her life. A grief response team will be in place to assist students and staff at Madera High School in handling this loss. Our counselors and school psychologist will work closely with this team as they make themselves available for students and staff. An increased level of individual and group counseling services will be available on a continual basis for as long as necessary. We ask everyone to remember Josephine’s compassion, kindness, love, thoughtfulness and sense of justice. As always, our Madera Unified School District Family will continue to support each other through this very difficult time.

May 20, 2019 at 9:05 PM ·

On May 11th, 2019 Solar Suitcase #543 built by sophomores Victor Cisneros, Richardo Yanez and Jacob Gomez, found its permanent home at Syekumulo R.C. Primary School in Bungoma, Kenya! (a Kibera slum near Nairobi)

Previously, the school had unreliable access to electricity, experiencing outages on a daily basis. With the addition of a sustainable energy source like the Solar Suitcase, the school will be able to light the classrooms, offices and library. This will increase study time for the students attending the school and will help them to achieve higher grades and better scores on entrance exams to higher education. The adults who work at the school will be able to charge their cell phones and other devices, as well as, benefit from added security.

To our three Stallion Scholars that built this amazing gift for our friends in Kenya, and their instructor Mr. Brian Richardson that led the way, we can’t express our immense pride in words. Nothing less than a priceless legacy, well done.
